section.p: The gnomy has a pot (identity) with soil (fairness) and a bonsai tree in it consisting of trunk and branches (why), flowers (how) and fruits (what). In order to bind the soil the gnomy plants flowers in the soil. Birds are moving into the crown of the tree.

p.strong: Flower & bee. The bee wants the nectar from flowers.

section.p: ConfigurationalA braid made of withered flowers next to the beehive.

Release tension Flower 1: A flower stalk that coils around the hive. The bee thinks there's something that wants to destroy the hive, and looks out. The bee then becomes happy to see the flower that unfortunately is closed.
Ambivalence Flower 1: One by one, the petals fall off and eventually even the middle of the flower.

Superiority Flower 2: The bee sees a flower outside the hive, and the flower is open. Fast, the bee flies there. Unfortunately, the flower is occupied by another bee that takes up all the place in the flower.

Incongruity Flower 3: The closed flower begins to vibrate and thinks that there is probably a caterpillar outside that wants to eat me. The flower remains closed, even if it is actually a bee that wants for the nectar.
Recognition Flower 3: The bee sees the semiopen flower and is getting ready to fly into it. The bee accelerates and at full speed it slams into the outside of a petal.
Surprise Flower 3: The bee comes to a flower that sleeps drooping. The bee buzzes a loud fanfare and the flower opens up and looks dizzyawake.
Embarisement Flower 3: The open flower is embarrassed to have exposed itself. The bee hums gently while slowly and gently flying into the flower.
